title: First U.S. Case Reported of Deadly Wuhan Virus

replies.msg:
A man in Wash­ing­ton state has been di­ag­nosed with the new Wuhan coro­n­avirus, ac­cord­ing to a per­son fa­mil­iar with the mat­ter, the first case re­ported in the U.S. from an out­break that has sick­ened hun­dreds of peo­ple in Asia.

The per­son re­cently trav­eled to Wuhan, China, the city where the out­break was first re­ported, the per­son said. The Cen­ters for Dis­ease Con­trol and Pre­ven­tion is ex­pected to dis­cuss the case dur­ing a news con­fer­ence later Tues­day.

The pa­tient is re­ported in good con­di­tion and is hos­pi­tal­ized out of an abun­dance of cau­tion.

U.S. of­fi­cials had said pre­vi­ously they ex­pect cases to be re­ported in the U.S. and were pre­paring for that pos­si­bil­ity.

Chi­nese health au­thor­i­ties have ac­knowl­edged that the coro­n­avirus has spread from one hu­man to an­other, height­en­ing con­cerns that the out­break could ex­pand fur­ther as tens of mil­lions of Chi­nese peo­ple travel for the Lu­nar New Year hol­i­day later this week.

More than 300 peo­ple have been sick­ened with the new virus, with at least six deaths, ac­cord­ing to Chi­nese au­thor­i­ties. While most of the con­firmed ill­nesses oc­curred in peo­ple in Wuhan, cases have been re­ported in other cities in China, as well as Thai­land, Japan, South Ko­rea and Tai­wan.

WSJ
Updated January 21, 2020 02:23 p.m. EST
